Issues.Title: Child Form Groups Don't Receive Updated _onCollectionChange() When FormGroupDirective Seeds Parent with Callback
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

We rely on `_onCollectionChange()` to notify its FormGroupDirective to re-bind its FormControlName directives, and FormGroup is smart enough to propagate its `_onCollectionChange()` callback so that Child FormGroups can notify too. This happens in two scenarios
1. [When we first initialize the FormGroup](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/4a030f7308b1e9c0fe6164f4533107f79004891c/packages/forms/src/model/form_group.ts#L598-L603) (the constructor calls `_setupControl()` which binds `_onCollectionChange()` to the children
2. [When we call](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/4a030f7308b1e9c0fe6164f4533107f79004891c/packages/forms/src/model/form_group.ts#L233-L239) `registerControl` (and associated methods)

The problem is with scenario 1: we may seed each child control with a default callback (an empty function) on init, but we don't propagate a *new* callback when we eventually bind the FormGroup to a FormGroupDirective. The child FormGroups are still working with the 'default' one. Furthermore the api is private so I don't see any way to fix this on the user side.

If we have a scenario where a child form group adds controls dynamically, and some of those controls are FormControlName directives (see stackblitz), then we fail to trigger `_updateDOMValue()` on the parent FormGroupDirective. The FormControlName directives are left with orphaned form controls.

Ideally, `_registerOnCollectionChange()`  would cascade to its children (or maybe just call `_setupControls()` again).

Issues.Title: Angular is decoding reserved characters from fragments
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

We use fragments (`#`) in the url to manage the search part of the state in our [redux based library](https://github.com/coveo/ui-kit/blob/master/packages/headless/README.md). When we encounter reserved characters in the state such as `&`, we use [encoreURIComponent](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/encodeURIComponent) to encode them. 

This works fine in most contexts. In the context of Angular we are encountering a problem where angular decodes those reserved characters and changes the url with the decoded part. 


Here is an example where `%26` is wrongfully changed into `&`.
https://kathleenwest.github.io/sample-angular-app/#q=This%26That
turns into 
https://kathleenwest.github.io/sample-angular-app/#q=This&That

This does not happen if we use query parameters (`?`)
https://kathleenwest.github.io/sample-angular-app/?q=This%26That
stays 
https://kathleenwest.github.io/sample-angular-app/?q=This%26That

Is this intended ? Why is angular decoding reserved characters in fragments ?

Issues.Title: Enhance renderMode Configuration for Angular Router
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

The introduction of the `renderMode` option in Angular Router is a fantastic feature, allowing developers to configure whether a route should be server-rendered, pre-rendered, or client-side rendered. However, the current implementation requires adding a separate configuration in the application's providers list, specifying which routes require SSR.

```
export const serverRoutes: ServerRoute[] = [
  {
    path: '**',
    renderMode: RenderMode.Server
  }
];
```

`provideServerRoutesConfig(serverRoutes)`

This approach, while functional, introduces redundancy and makes the configuration less intuitive.

**Proposal**:

Allow specifying the renderMode directly within the route definition itself. This would streamline the configuration, making it more straightforward and easier to understand. Developers could define the rendering mode for each route without needing a separate list in the providers.

**Example**:

```
import { Routes, RenderMode } from '@angular/router';

const routes: Routes = [
  {
    path: '',
    component: HomeComponent,
    renderMode: RenderMode.Server
  },
  {
    path: 'about',
    component: AboutComponent,
    renderMode: RenderMode.Prerender
  },
  {
    path: 'dashboard',
    component: DashboardComponent,
    renderMode: RenderMode.Client // Default
  }
];
```

**Benefits**:

- Simplified Configuration: No need for a separate provider configuration. The renderMode is specified where routes are defined.
- Better Readability: The rendering mode is directly associated with the route, making it easier to understand at a glance.
- Reduced Redundancy: Avoids the need to maintain a separate list of server-rendered routes, reducing the risk of mismatch or errors.
- Backward Compatibility:

If the renderMode property is not specified in the route, it would default to RenderMode.Client, ensuring backward compatibility.

Issues.Title: perf(@angular/build): reuse TS package.json cache when rebuilding
Issues.Body:
TypeScript 5.6 and higher added functionality that will search for a `package.json` file for source files that are part of the program (e.g., `.d.ts`) and within a node modules directory. This can be an expensive tasks especially considering the large amount of `.d.ts` files within packages. TypeScript supports using a cache of known `package.json` files to improve the performance of this task. The Angular CLI will now provide and reuse this cache across rebuilds during watch mode. This includes the use of `ng serve`.

The performance difference is most apparent for the Angular template diagnostic step of the build. Internally the Angular compiler creates a new template typechecking program which causes the `package.json` search process to occur. By leveraging the cache, this process becomes a series of cache hits. In the event that files are modified within the node modules directory, the cache is invalidated and the following rebuild may be longer as a result.

(cherry picked from commit 75998ebabb041f60aab40bf5a11979e8f3615537)

Issues.Title: bug(mat.theme-overrides): Overridden CSS properties not displaying correctly in IDE hints
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

This is simply a quality of life improvement request.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/aa8104c0-6103-44c7-8482-f96ae4d51fa9)

I've overridden `on-surface` and `surface` in [the recommended manner](https://material.angular.io/guide/theming#system-tokens), but the IDE (IntelliJ in this screenshot) won't pick those modifications up.

The rendered page in the browser shows the correct colour, this is strictly an issue within the IDE.

The concern is that deeper into the project, when a developer is using Material CSS variables, the colour hints will not match what they are expecting (and needing) which will cause confusion and potentially result in additional variables being created by the developer that aren't actually needed, just so the IDE hints match their expectations.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. add Material to an Angular project
2. override a theme variable such as `surface`
3. use the matching CSS property in a rule (`--mat-sys-on-surface` in this example)
4. observe that the IDE colour hint does not match the overridden value

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/aa8104c0-6103-44c7-8482-f96ae4d51fa9)


### Expected Behavior

The colour hints in the sidebar should show the overridden colour(s) instead of the defaults.

### Actual Behavior

What I see in the sidebar are the defaults for the current theme.

### Environment

- Angular: 19.0.3
- CDK/Material: 19.0.2
- Browser(s): N/A
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
- IDE: IntelliJ IDEA 2024.3 (Ultimate Edition)

Issues.Title: bug(Menu): fix menu panels not closing when no trigger is present
Issues.Body:

No.

### Description

MenuPanels cannot be closed when they do not have an active trigger set.
A scenario where unsetting the trigger during runtime may be wanted is when the button is meant to open a context menu or a bottom sheet depending on the size of the viewport and so needs to switch between a click handler (that opens a bottom sheet) or a matMenu Trigger that opens a menu panel during runtime. 4. Now upsize the window width until the button says "no Trigger" - ensure that the menu panel remains open during that time
5. Try clicking a menu option or anywhere in the app window that would normally close the MatMenuPanel

### Expected Behavior

The menu panel closes when an option is selected or anywhere within the app window outside the menu panel is clicked.

### Actual Behavior

When the trigger to open the menu is lost - the menu panel can no longer close until it regains a trigger.
